State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes & Membrane Processes College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 People’s Republic of China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, People’s Republic of China. State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 People’s Republic of China Graphical abstract A series of B2O3 modified Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared for the hydrogenolysis of glucose. The catalysts were fully characterized by BET, ICP, N2O adsorptive decomposition, XRD, SEM, TG, H2-TPR, CO-FTIR, XPS, and NH3-TPD. The strong interaction between B2O3 and CuO could promote the dispersion of copper and inhibit the reduction of CuO, creating a proper mol ratio of Cuδ+/Cu0 for the hydrogenolysis of glucose to oxygen-containing chemicals. Furthermore, the doping of B2O3 also introduced more acid sites onto the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts, which is favorable for the cleavage of hydroxyl through dehydration. Therefore, the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose to 1,2-propanediol was dependent on the contribution of Cuδ+, Cu0, and acid sites. The catalytic activity and 1,2-propanediol selectivity were improved significantly by doping B2O3 into Cu/Al2O3. Among the catalysts, 1CuB/Al2O3 showed the highest selectivity for 1,2-propanediol, with the value of 49.5% at 96.6% conversion of glucose. Keywords B2O3 Cu/Al2O3 Glucose Hydrogenolysis 1,2-Propanediol 1 Introduction The exploration and utilization of renewable resources has gained increasing attention [1,2]. Among the renewable resources, such as biomass, solar, wind energy, geothermal, etc., biomass, as the only sustainable carbon resource, has the potential to provide renewable high value-added chemicals and oxygenated liquid fuels [3]. Cellulose, which is the main component of lignocellulose in nature, is composed of glucose monomers through β-1,4-glucosidic bonds [4]. Recently, the successful decomposition of cellulose by acid and enzyme encourages us to study the catalytic conversion of glucose [5,6], which could not only produce chemicals and fuels, but also help us understanding the complex reaction process of biomass at the molecular level. Considering the excessive amount of hydroxyl groups in the glucose molecule, the selective elimination of surplus oxygen atoms is one of the major challenges in biomass conversion. In this respect, hydrogenolysis, which could selectively break CC and CO bonds, has been regarded as an efficient and economical method [7]. Furthermore, many value-added chemicals such as 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) and C1-C6 alkanes can be obtained from the hydrogenolysis of glucose. Especially, the hydrogenolysis of saccharides and alditols to 1,2-PDO has attracted increasing interest recently [8–11]. Furthermore, compared with cellulose, the hydrogenolysis of saccharides can be operated in a continuous system with high concentration, which makes it a more efficient and energy saving reaction process [12,13]. Usually, basic auxiliaries (such as Ca(OH)2 and NaOH) were added to enhance CC bond cleavage [11,14–17], which resulted in a difficult and expensive separation process. Moreover, the metal-oxide bifunctional catalysts, which are more convenient and efficient for biomass hydrogenolysis, have been widely studied. It is reported everywhere that, the metal sites in the catalyst are mainly responsible for the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions. The acid sites on the metal oxides could catalyze CO bond breaking through dehydration reaction [18–23]. Based on the reaction mechanism of saccharides, it has been suggested that the metal and oxide components in the bifunctional catalyst could catalyze the tandem reactions of biomass to value-added chemicals. Furthermore, the selective conversion of glucose is dependent on the reasonable modulation of the structure and properties of the metals and oxides [24,25]. For example, SnO2 has been used to modify the Ru/AC catalysts for glucose conversion. The highly dispersed SnO2 could improve 1,2-PDO yield, with the value of 25% on the optimal 5%Ru3%Sn/AC catalyst [8]. Among the bifunctional catalysts, Cu has often been used as the active metal in biomass conversion due to its tunable hydrogenolysis activity [26,27]. γ-Al2O3, which has abundant acid sites, is benefit for saccharide and polyols hydrogenolysis [28,29]. For example, Vila has prepared Cu-Al2O3 catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [30]. The results indicate that the acid property of Al2O3 has an important effect on glycerol hydrogenolysis. Boron is suggested to be an efficient promotor to improve the stability and selectivity of transition metal, which has been widely studied on the hydrogenation reaction [31–34]. Furthermore, the doping of B2O3 could not only affect the physicochemical properties of Cu, but also influence the hydrogenolysis activity. For example, Zhao has prepared the Cu-B2O3/SiO2 bifunctional catalyst, in which B2O3 could promote the dispersion and stability of Cu when a proper amount of boron was introduced [31]. The CuB/SiO2 catalyst system had been prepared and used for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol [34]. The results turned out that the introduction of B2O3 onto the CuB/SiO2 catalyst brought new acid sites. In this text, B2O3 was used to modify the structure and properties of Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. The role of B2O3 on the properties and activity of CuB/Al2O3 catalysts for glucose transformation was studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Boric oxide (B2O3) modified Cu/Al2O3 (labeled as CuB/Al2O3) catalysts were prepared with a stepwise impregnation method. Firstly, B2O3 was deposited on γ-Al2O3 with an aqueous solution of boric acid for 12 h. The precursor was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and then impregnated with Cu(NO3)2 solution. The impregnated material was dried for 12 h at 80 °C and calcined for 4 h at 350 °C. The samples were denoted as yCuB/Al2O3, in which y% refers to the designed weight loading of Boric oxide (y = 1, 3, 5, 7). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The contents of copper and B2O3 were detected on ICP-OES (Optima2100DV, PerkinEler). N2 physical adsorption was performed on an ASAP 2420 (micromeritics) apparatus. The catalysts were vacuumed for 8 h at 350 °C prior to the measurements. The metallic copper surface area was measured with the N2O chemisorption method reported before [35,36]. Typically, 200 mg sample was reduced for 2 h in H2 at 250 °C, and then flushed with Ar flow for 1 h. 10 vol.% N2O/N2 flow was used for the oxidation of surface Cu species at 50 °C for 30 min, following by being flushed for 30 min with Ar flow. Then the consumption of H2 was monitored by a TCD detector. XRD spectra were acquired on a D/max-RA apparatus, using Cu Kα radiation. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on JSM-6360LV (JEOL, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was operated on Netzsch STA 2500 in air. The samples were heated to 1000 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min. H2-TPR experiments of the catalysts were performed on Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. The temperature was increased to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in 10 vol.% H2/Ar flow. The XPS spectra were measured on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The calcined sample was in situ reduced for 2 h in H2 at 250 °C. NH3-TPD patterns were obtained on Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. In a typical run, 200 mg catalysts were pretreated for 2 h at 250 °C in H2 flow. After, the catalyst was flushed for 60 min in helium at 250 °C and cooled to 100 °C. The sample was flushed with ammonia and then purged with helium for 1 h. The TPD pattern was started to record in the temperature range of 100–800 °C. 2.3 Catalytic reaction process A fixed-bed reactor system was used for the hydrogenolysis of glucose. First, 2.0 g catalysts were loaded and reduced for 2 h in H2 at 250 °C. Subsequently, the glucose aqueous solution (5 wt%) was introduced to the gas flow with a high-pressure infusion pump. The liquid products were analyzed off-line on an HPLC with an RID detector. The total carbon (TC) balance was calculated based on the following equation: TC % = carbon mol of products and reactant after reaction carbon mol of reactant in feedstock × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties of the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts The contents of copper detected by ICP-OES are nearly the same as designed. The detected contents of B2O3 were close to the designed values. The surface area of the catalysts increased with the increase of B2O3 loading from 263.5 m2/g of Cu/Al2O3 to 279.6 m2/g of 3CuB/Al2O3. Then it decreased with the B2O3 contents further increasing. However, the surface areas of the catalysts with B2O3 doping were higher than that of Cu/Al2O3, which suggested that new surface was formed by doping B2O3. The pore volume decreased slightly with B2O3 contents increasing, indicating that the pore was blocked when a high amount of B2O3 was doped (Table 1). Fig. 1 displays the crystalline structures of the calcined CuB/Al2O3 catalysts. Only the XRD peaks of γ-Al2O3 at 37.4, 46.0, and 67.0° were observed [37]. However, no signals about B2O3 and CuO were detected, which suggested that B2O3 and CuO nanoparticles were well dispersed on the catalyst surface. 3.2 H2-TPR To study the reducibility of CuO on the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts, H2-TPR was performed (Fig. 2 ). The reduction pattern of Cu/Al2O3 showed one main reduction peak with a shoulder peak. The reduction peak at 203 °C is attributed to CuO nanoparticles with high dispersion. The reduction peak shifted to a higher temperature with the increase of B2O3 contents, which indicates the strong interaction between B2O3 and CuO. The shoulder peak at around 270 °C was attributed to large CuO nanoparticles [34,38]. However, the shoulder peak disappeared gradually with the increase of B2O3 contents, which illustrates that the doping of B2O3 could enhance the dispersion of copper. N2O adsorptive decomposition was carried out to measure copper surface area. The results turned out that the exposed Cu surface area on CuB/Al2O3 catalysts decreased with the increase of B2O3 contents. Combining the H2-TPR patterns with the metallic copper areas measured by N2O chemisorption, it was supposed that the B2O3 species had both dispersion and coverage effects on copper sites [39]. 3.3 CO-DRIFT CO-DRIFT experiments were performed to study the chemical environment of Cu in CuB/Al2O3 (Fig. 3 ). According to the previous reports, the IR bands assigned to the linear adsorption of CO on copper are often below 2140 cm−1, which are changeable according to the chemical environment of copper [40]. All the catalysts showed a broad peak at around 2050–2140 cm−1, indicating the high dispersion of metallic copper nanoparticles. An obvious blue shift of the bands was observed with B2O3 contents increasing, which demonstrates that B2O3 has strong electronic effects on Cu. 3.4 Chemical states of Cu species The Cu 2p XPS spectra were obtained to study the chemical state of copper (Fig. 4 A). The broad peak at 933.7 eV with a satellite peak in Fig. 4A indicates that CuO species could not be completely reduced, with partial Cu2+ species existing on the reduced catalyst. The reduction degree of Cu species was also analyzed by Cu LMM XAES spectra. The results showed that there were both Cu0 and Cuδ+ (δ ≥ 1) species existed on the reduced catalyst [35]. Furthermore, compared with the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, the ratios of Cuδ+/(Cuδ+ + Cu0) were higher on the catalysts with B2O3 doping, which confirmed the strong electronic effect between B2O3 and copper. Furthermore, the highest ratio of Cuδ+/(Cuδ+ + Cu0) was obtained on 1CuB/Al2O3. 3.5 NH3-TPD The NH3-TPD patterns were recorded to study the acidity of the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 5 A). All the reduced catalysts showed a broad ammonia desorption peak at 130–500 °C. With B2O3 contents increasing, the amount of acid sites calculated based on the adsorbed NH3 decreased as follows: 7CuB/Al2O3 (115.5 mmol/g) > 5CuB/Al2O3 (101.4 mmol/g) > 3CuB/Al2O3 (90.7 mmol/g) > 1CuB/Al2O3 (80.5 mmol/g) > Cu/Al2O3 (73.9 mmol/g). The ratio of the acid amount to B2O3 added has also been analyzed (Fig. 5B). An almost linear relationship between the amount of the acid sites and the content of B2O3 was obtained, which indicated that the new acid sites were mainly provided by the doped B2O3 species. 3.6 The hydrogenolysis of glucose Fig. 6 shows the catalytic performance versus WHSV. As shown in Fig. 6A, all the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts with B2O3 doped showed higher glucose conversion than that of Cu/Al2O3. Sorbitol selectivities on CuB/Al2O3 with B2O3 doping were lower than that on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. Furthermore, 1CuB/Al2O3 showed the lowest sorbitol selectivity. The 3CuB/Al2O3, 5CuB/Al2O and 7CuB/Al2O3 catalysts display similar sorbitol selectivities. The glycerol selectivity in Fig. 6C showed a special order. With the increase of B2O3 contents, glycerol selectivity decreased first and then increased. The lowest glycerol selectivity was shown on 1CuB/Al2O3. Furthermore, the catalysts with B2O3 doping showed higher 1,2-PDO selectivity than Cu/Al2O3. The optimal value of 49.5% at 96.6% glucose conversion was obtained on 1CuB/Al2O3. The results illustrated that B2O3 could promote the hydrogenolysis of glucose. 3.7 Correlation between the properties and performance of CuB/Al2O3 B2O3 has been widely used as an additive for various catalysts due to its structure and electronic effects [33,34]. Based on the N2O-TPD and H2-TPR results, the close contact between B2O3 and copper not only promotes the dispersion of copper but also has a coverage effect on copper species, resulting in the decrease of copper surface area with the increase of B2O3 contents. The coverage and dispersion effects have been widely reported in the case of WOx [29], B2O3 [32], MoOx [41], etc. For example, Zhu et al. have prepared the CuB/SiO2 catalysts. They suggested that the doping of B2O3 could inhibit the agglomeration of copper species during the heating treatment and facilitate the formation of small CuO nanoparticles. As revealed by H2-TPR, CO-DRIFTS, and Cu LMM XAES results, the close contact between B2O3 and copper resulted in a strong electron interaction, which inhibited the reduction of CuO and decreased the ratio of Cu0/Cuδ+ on the reduced catalysts. Additionally, the doping of B2O3 introduced more acidity sites onto the catalysts. The hydrogenolysis of glucose to 1,2-PDO undergoes some tandem reactions, as shown in Scheme 1 [29]: (1) the isomerization of glucose to fructose; (2) The CC bond cleavage of fructose to dihydroxyacetone and glyceraldehyde through retro aldol condensation reaction, which is supposed to be conducted on metal sites; (3) The CO bond cleavage of dihydroxyacetone and glyceraldehyde through dehydration reaction; (4) The hydrogenation of the intermediates. As previously suggested, sorbitol is obtained by the hydrogenation of glucose, which acts as the competitive reaction with the retro aldol condensation reaction [29]. Moreover, the selectivity of 1,2-PDO, the percent of Cuδ+ ( X C u δ + ), the surface area of Cu (SCu), and the amount of acid sites on different CuB/Al2O3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 7 . The results demonstrated that, with the increasing B2O3 content, the acid amounts increased while the copper surface area decreased. Accordingly, the optimal 1,2-PDO selectivity was achieved on the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst. The hydrogenolysis of glucose has been performed on the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 300 °C. The results turned out that the conversion of glucose was lower than that on the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst reduced at 250 °C. Furthermore, the reduction temperature of 1CuB/Al2O3 also affected the selectivity of products. For example, the selectivity of sorbitol was higher than that on 1CuB/Al2O3 reduced at 250 °C. Correspondingly, the selectivity of 1,2-propanediol decreased when 1CuB/Al2O3 was reduced at higher temperature. We speculated that the high-temperature reduction changed the ratio of Cu/Cuδ+ and caused the aggregation of Cu species, which resulted in the lower hydrogenolysis activity of the catalyst. Considering the tandem reaction process, it suggested that 1,2-PDO selectivity was determined by both the acidic and metal sites. An interesting found was that 1,2-PDO selectivity displayed nearly the same trend with the Cuδ+ percent on the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts. It seems that the proportion of Cuδ+/Cu0 plays great roles on the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose. The 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst after reaction was also characterized by XPS and XAES to detect the ratio of Cu cation to Cu metal (Fig. 4 and Table 2 ). The Cu 2p XPS spectra of the used 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst displayed the similar results to the reduced 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst, which indicates the presence of both Cu0 and Cuδ+ species. Furthermore, the XAES results turned out that the percentage of Cuδ+ was 77%, which is much higher than that on the reduced 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst. We speculate that the small Cu nanoparticles on the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst are prone to be oxidized in air. It has been reported that the metal cations such as Snx+ and Wx+ on the solid catalysts could act as Lewis acid in the hydrogenolysis of saccharides, which could catalyze the isomerization between glucose and fructose [29,42]. Furthermore, many researchers also pointed out that the Cuδ+ species on the reduced copper-based catalysts could function as Lewis acid sites [29,43,44]. It can be concluded that the electronic deficient Cuδ+ species could provide Lewis acid sites, which can catalyze the isomerization reaction. Furthermore, many researchers also found that the retro aldol condensation reaction could be promoted by Lewis acid sites [21–23]. For example, a bifunctional Ru-WOx catalyst has been used for the hydrogenolysis of glucose by Liu et al [21]. They pointed out that WOx could promote the retro aldol condensation reaction. Vilcocq pointed out that Lewis acid sites could change to L-OH- Brønsted basic sites in association with water and promote retro aldol condensation reaction [23]. Therefore, the Cuδ+ species, which act as Lewis acid, are proposed to promote the retro aldol condensation reaction. Moreover, the acid sites could also catalyze the dehydration of C3 intermediates. Therefore, it was proposed that the Cuδ+ species could tune the reaction rate of elementary reactions and enhance 1,2-PDO selectivity. Furthermore, the adjustment of Cu0/Cuδ+ could also modify the hydrogenation activity and decrease sorbitol selectivity. Based on the reaction mechanism, it was proposed that the acid sites provided by Al2O3 or B2O3 could promote the isomerization of glucose to fructose, the retro aldol condensation of fructose to unsaturated intermediates, and the dehydration of the intermediates [45]. Cu metal sites are mainly responsible for the hydrogenation of glucose and the intermediates, which can be easily conducted at mild conditions [46]. Furthermore, the retro aldol condensation reaction could also be carried out on Cu metal sites. In this respect, the presence of Cuδ+ could tune the activity of different elementary reactions. For example, the Cuδ+ species could act as acid sites, which could enhance the isomerization, retro aldol condensation and dehydration reactions. Overall, the doping of B2O3 could tune the properties of metal and acid sites on CuB/Al2O3, which could enhance 1,2-PDO selectivity (Table 3 ). 3.8 The stability of the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst The stability of the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst has been evaluated (Fig. 8 ). The results turned out that the catalyst could be operated over 120 h without obvious deactivation. The 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst after the long-term operation has been characterized by XRD, SEM, TG and ICP (Fig. 9 ). The XRD pattern of the used catalyst displayed the diffraction peaks of boehmite at 14.4, 28.1, and 38.3° (JCPDS 05-0190), which suggested that the AlOOH structure had been formed in the hydrothermal condition. The SEM images of the calcined and spent catalysts displayed that the catalyst was broken down into smaller particles after the long-term operation, which could be due to the effect of the phase transformation of γ-Al2O3. Considering the stability of the catalyst, it suggested that the phase transformation of γ-Al2O3 had little effect on glucose hydrogenolysis. Furthermore, Wu et al. have compared the activity of Cu/boehmite and Cu/γ-Al2O3 on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO [47]. The results turned out that Cu/boehmite showed higher glycerol conversion and 1,2-PDO selectivity, which was ascribed to the small size of Cu metal clusters stabilized by boehmite and the enhanced dehydration of the intermediate by the Lewis acid sites of boehmite. The mass change of the 1CuB/Al2O3 catalyst before and after reaction has been quantified by TG analysis in air atmosphere (Table 4 ). The results turned out that the weight loss of the used catalyst was larger than the calcined catalyst when they were heated to 1000 °C in air, which was supposed to be caused by the dehydration of boehmite and the removal of coke on the used catalyst. Therefore, considering the mass change caused by the phase transformation and coke on the surface of 1CuB/Al2O3, the contents of Cu and B2O3 measured by ICP-OES were calibrated with the TG results. The values were a little lower than that on the calcined catalyst, which indicated the stability of Cu and B2O3 on the catalyst surface. 4 Conclusion B2O3 could improve the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles and create new acid sites on CuB/Al2O3. However, the close contact between B2O3 and Cu also decreases the Cu surface area due to the overlap effect. The decorated B2O3 on the Cu surface has strong electronic effect on Cu, which tunes the proportion of Cuδ+/Cu0. The doping of B2O3 could enhance 1,2-PDO selectivity, with the optimal value of 49.5% on 1CuB/Al2O3. Cu0, Cuδ+ and B2O3 have synergistic effect on the hydrogenolysis of glucose, which could promote the selectivity of C3 polyols. Especially, the Cuδ+ species, which is supposed to act as Lewis acid, could catalyze the elementary reactions in the transformation of glucose to 1,2-PDO. coredata.dc:description: A series of B2O3 modified Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared for the hydrogenolysis of glucose. The catalysts were fully characterized by BET, ICP, N2O adsorptive decomposition, XRD, SEM, TG, H2-TPR, CO-FTIR, XPS, and NH3-TPD. The strong interaction between B2O3 and CuO could promote the dispersion of copper and inhibit the reduction of CuO, creating a proper mol ratio of Cuδ+/Cu0 for the hydrogenolysis of glucose to oxygen-containing chemicals. Furthermore, the doping of B2O3 also introduced more acid sites onto the CuB/Al2O3 catalysts, which is favorable for the cleavage of hydroxyl through dehydration. Therefore, the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose to 1,2-propanediol was dependent on the contribution of Cuδ+, Cu0, and acid sites. The catalytic activity and 1,2-propanediol selectivity were improved significantly by doping B2O3 into Cu/Al2O3. Among the catalysts, 1CuB/Al2O3 showed the highest selectivity for 1,2-propanediol, with the value of 49.5% at 96.6% conversion of glucose.
coredata.dc:title: Boron oxide modified bifunctional Cu/Al2O3 catalysts for the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose to 1,2-propanediol
